text.p: These are the headlines from selected Canadian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Bre-X displays Midas touch: High-flying Canadian firm gets Indonesian nod to mine world's richest gold strike.
- Ralph Klein pursues the city PCs lost: Edmonton victory will have a price.
- Revenue drives deficit success: Ottawa's cutting plays small part.
- Phonics reading method best, study finds: Whole-language approach significantly less effective, Houston research shows.
- Ontario prepares negligence defence: Environment officials fear lawsuits.
- Activist spinning wheels in crusade against AIDS: A Canadian has found little sympathy internationally. His belongings were even taken during a TV session in Casablanca.
- Bre-X deal shuts out Barrick: Hefty balance sheet, impressive connections not enough for Peter Munk to win gold.

- The Internet not exactly Main Street for doing business: Only one in 20 companies are doing doing deals on the Net, a poll has found. Security and a lack of cost-benefit analysis are just two factors.
- Gulf ready to grab control of Clyde: Has a lock on almost 41 percent of British oil company's shares.
- More banks, trusts cut mortgage rates.
- Bre-X seals Busang deal, Barrick gets nothing: Move means Bre-X keeps 45 percent of what could be the greatest gold find in history.
- Canadian 88 to donate C$1 million of Morrison spoils.
